author: gcolvin
content:
I'd like to clear up some confusions about the JVM and Wasm that arose yesterday.  I needed a chance to check the manuals to be sure I had it right.

The JVM has _jsr_ and _ret_ instructions that were once used for implementing _finally_ clauses.  These are not subroutines in the usual sense, despite their names and descriptions.  Those are supported by a set of _invoke_ and _return_ opcodes.  _invokestatic_ amounts to a direct subroutine call - it is defined within a class, but not bound to an object.  The remainder are bound to objects.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jvms/se8/html/jvms-6.html#jvms-6.5.invokestatic

Wasm, on the other hand, supports _call_, which is a direct subroutine call,  and *call_indirect* which calls through a table of functions.
https://webassembly.github.io/spec/core/syntax/instructions.html#syntax-instr-control

*JUMPSUB*, since it takes its argument on the stack, can be used for direct or indirect calls, depending on whether its argument is constant.

author: pauld.9606
content:
Aha, now I understand.

Forth has a second stack called the "return stack".

Hmmm. I thought that a second stack should be avoided on modern hardware to prevent stack collision and thrashing. I wonder why Forth has a second stack..

The designer of Forth also had hardware ambitions, and owns a hardware company which implements Forth in hardware!

Forth cpus do not use registers, but stacks. In hardware, a second stack may not be such a bad idea. For example, in hardware, one can implement interrupts to handle stack overflow/underflow/collision. In hardware, one can use the second stack to implement jump pre-fetching tricks (as we saw with RISC-V above).

Of course, there are down-sides of stacks in hardware, in particular the size limits, and possible thrashing if overflows are put in memory.

I think that we should celebrate the history and ingenuity of Forth, especially since it influenced Bitcoin Script which influenced EVM.

But we should not base a second stack design on something with which had different ambitions and limitations.

One interesting fact about Forth hardware -- it is popular for space exploration!

author: gcolvin
content:
> Copied from issue, which was closed as I typed.
While waiting for my girlfriend to come celebrate my birthday I took time to listen in on the meeting and review the notes above.

I'd like to thank Peter for his comment on the "nastiness" of this decision and its follow-on effects. For myself, I am left to seriously reconsider my future involvement with the Ethereum project. And to seriously question whether I could in good conscience advise others to participate. Unless they enjoy chaos and disappointment.

It is true that a single technical concern (whether to bear the cost to prevent branching into subroutines) remained active for some time after initial acceptance, as I attempted to give it the best consideration I could. In the end, as author, I made the choice not to accept the change, for reasons I stated at the time -- from the very start I meant this proposal to be a very small change to provide subroutines with Forth semantics, and not to impose syntactic restrictions.

The issue was not raised again until Christian made a comment - not on the ACD channel, but on Twitter - that for him it remained a blocking objection. That objection left me - unprepared and at the last minute - trying to field objections and explain decisions long since made. I should not have needed to do that.

author: gcolvin
content:
I put some degree of blame on the client teams themselves. Before implementing, testing, and scheduling an EIP for an upgrade I believe it falls on them to do their own due diligence. To be convinced that the EIP is really an improvement to the protocol, and be able to justify their decision.

And Hudson, thank you for keeping the discussion respectful and on track, as disappointed as I am in the outcome. I hope this sad turn of affairs leads to some serious soul-searching -- we have tasked ourselves with the research, development, and management of a network with a current market capitalization of $173 billion USD. I have no clue how many businesses are building on that network, or how many livelihoods it supports. We must learn to operate like professionals.

We always end up shifting schedules based on the work, vs. the other way around. We've delayed ~every hard fork so far because "something" wasn't ready, and we've almost never kicked something out because of a date. It feels obvious that you _should_ have done that in hindsight when you analyse it, but when you are in the process of getting it done, the bias seems much more on the work itself vs. the timelines. 

I think if we can agree to "anchor EIPs" for forks, then we can limit the scope (no fork has two anchors) and it also makes it easier to drop a non-anchor EIP if it becomes problematic (kind of like we did with Berlin & BLS).

author: pipermerriam
content: Do any of the clients have solid architectures that allow flagging individual eips on and off?  We built Py-EVM to be reasonably modular in its architecture but feature flagging individual eips isn't something we ever worked on or had a clean answer for.

author: sky.cactus

content: I don't want to say with 100% certainty, but I believe it is usually just a config file that has `EIP-XXX: <folk_block_number>` or something along those lines.

author: pipermerriam
content: Maybe that's just something we failed at getting architecturally correct in py-evm.

author: sky.cactus
content: Nethermind, for example, I believe releases clients with future EIPs coded in, and simply not enabled in config.

author: axic3354
content: Keep in mind a lot of EIPs require major architectural changes (for example in the EVM) which makes it hard to be fully modular without compromising speed or other considerations.

author: pipermerriam
content: Supposing we *could* put a self-imposed hard-ish requirement that EIPS be able to be enabled/disabled individually, then that would allow for staggered implementations, and only forking at the point where all clients have fully implemented.  Probably necessary to leave room for flexibility since certain EIPs won't be condusive to flagging on/off.

author: pipermerriam
content:
But without this, it's hard for me to see eip-centric working due to the coordination costs and nature of client development.

- coordination cost:  Tendency for an EIP to need an initial implementation to figure out hidden problems.  Once the leading implementation is done, how do you get the other clients to prioritize their implementations....
- nature of client development:  Teams are always operating at 100% capacity.  They have their own roadmaps and priorities.  Just because client A finished implementing an EIP doesn't mean that it becomes a priority for client B.  Often, the functionality in EIPs isn't even beneficial to the client, it's just EVM features that are desired at the application layer so there's little intrinsic motivation....

author: pipermerriam
content: I don't think it is an actionable solution, but Alexey's interest in more modular client design, allowing multiple clients to share the same EVM or Storage engine, might take us in a direction that makes this situation better, since two (or more) clients could share a single implementation, allowing multiple clients to benefit from a single implementation of an EIP...    It has the nice property of aligning interests, but I question whether the reality of this approach would actually work in practice.

author: sky.cactus
content:

I think we can enforce this because I *think* we already have it.  Definitely need to get confirmation from the individual teams.

author: Deleted User
content: my opinion about all that is that pretty much any process changes will be "overfitting". None of the core dev teams is operating at a sufficient scale (in terms of resources and roadmaps) for us to be able to generalise their behaviour and come up with the way to perhaps modify it. And there aren't many of these teams. Until we get to such scale, it might be more useful to have a process which does not use abstract terms, but very concrete entities and people, for example, go-ethereum, Peter, Martin, Tomasz, Nethermind, and so on. Yes, this means the process can be asymmetric, but it might be much more honest and efficient this way. If we lucky enough that this process becomes so large and list of people involved too big, we can generalise it and express it in more abstract terms. But doing it now feels like constantly "overfitting", undershooting or overshooting
